trans-unit.source: Manages a collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Visual"></xref> objects.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual> class is used as a container for a collection of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual> objects.

The <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingVisual> class derives from the <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual> class, such that the <xref:System.Windows.Media.DrawingVisual> class can also contain a collection of visual objects.
Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref> class.
Gets or sets a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Effects.BitmapEffect"></xref> value for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
The bitmap effect for this visual object.
Gets or sets a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Effects.BitmapEffectInput"></xref> value for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
The bitmap effect input value for this visual object.
Gets or sets a cached representation of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Set the <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual.CacheMode%2A> property when you need to increase performance for content that is time-consuming to render.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Media.CacheMode"></xref> that holds a cached representation of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Gets the child collection of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Media.VisualCollection"></xref> that contains the children of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Gets or sets the clipping region of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> that defines the clipping region.
Gets the bounding box for the contents of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.

Use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual.DescendantBounds%2A> property to return the union of all the content bounding boxes for all of the descendants of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual> object, but not the object itself.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Rect"></xref> that specifies the bounding box.

Gets the union of all the content bounding boxes for all of the descendants of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>, but not including the contents of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Get the <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual.ContentBounds%2A> property to return the cached bounding box rectangle for the <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual> itself.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Rect"></xref> that specifies the combination bounding box.
Gets or sets the bitmap effect to apply to the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Effects.Effect"></xref> that represents the bitmap effect.
Returns a specified child <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Visual"></xref> for the parent <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
By default, a <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual> does not have any children.
A 32-bit signed integer that represents the index value of the child <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Visual"></xref>.
The value of index must be between 0 and - 1.
The child <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Visual"></xref>.
Returns the top-most visual object of a hit test by specifying a <xref href="System.Windows.Point"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.HitTestResult.VisualHit%2A> property of the return value represents the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual> object that was hit.
The point value to hit test.
The hit test result of the visual returned as a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.HitTestResult"></xref> type.

Initiates a hit test on the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref> by using the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.HitTestFilterCallback"></xref> and <xref href="System.Windows.Media.HitTestResultCallback"></xref> objects.
The `filterCallback` parameter can be null, in which case, it is ignored.
If `filterCallback` is not `null`, it is invoked before `resultCallback`.
The delegate that allows you to ignore parts of the visual tree that you are not interested in processing in your hit test results.
The delegate that is used to control the return of hit test information.
Defines the set of parameters for a hit test.
Gets or sets the offset value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref> from its reference point.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Vector"></xref> that represents the offset value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Gets or sets the opacity of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>, based on 0=transparent, 1=opaque.
A value from 0 through 1 that specifies a range from fully transparent to fully opaque.

A value of 0 indicates that the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref> is completely transparent, while a value of 1 indicates that the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref> is completely opaque.
A value 0.5 indicates 50 percent opaque, a value of 0.725 indicates 72.5 percent opaque, and so on.
Values less than 0 are treated as 0, while values greater than 1 are treated as 1.
Gets or sets a brush that specifies a possible opacity mask for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Opacity masks can be used to create effects such as vignettes, based on the alpha channel values of the brush.
A value of type <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Brush"></xref> that represents the opacity mask value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Gets the parent <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Visual"></xref> for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Note that this is returned as <xref:System.Windows.DependencyObject>, rather than a raw object.
This property might return `null` in a disconnected tree, or if you have traversed to the tree root at the window level.
The parent of the visual.
Gets or sets the transform that is applied to the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
<xref:System.Windows.Media.Transform> is a base class that unifies many different forms of transforms.
For details, see <xref:System.Windows.Media.Transform>.
The transform value.
Gets the number of children for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
By default, a <xref:System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual> does not have any children.
The number of children in the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.VisualCollection"></xref> of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Gets or sets the X (horizontal) guideline for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Pixel snapping is the process in which content layout is fixed so that object edges are rendered on device-specific pixels.
The [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] graphics system uses device-independent units to enable resolution and device independence.
Each device independent pixel automatically scales with the system's [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dpi](~/includes/tlasharptla-dpi-md.md)] setting.

This provides [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] applications proper scaling for different [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_dpi](~/includes/tla2sharptla-dpi-md.md)] settings and makes the application automatically [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_dpi](~/includes/tla2sharptla-dpi-md.md)]-aware.
However, this [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_dpi](~/includes/tla2sharptla-dpi-md.md)] independence can create irregular edge rendering due to anti-aliasing.
These artifacts, commonly seen as blurry, or "soft" edges, can occur when the location of an edge falls in the middle of a device pixel rather than between device pixels.

To address this issue, [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] provides a way for object edges in a visual tree to "snap" to device pixels through pixel snapping, eliminating the soft edges produced by anti-aliasing.
The horizontal guideline.
Gets or sets the Y (vertical) guideline for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual"></xref>.
Pixel snapping is the process in which content layout is fixed so that object edges are rendered on device-specific pixels.
The [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] graphics system uses device-independent units to enable resolution and device independence.
Each device independent pixel automatically scales with the system's [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dpi](~/includes/tlasharptla-dpi-md.md)] setting.

This provides [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] applications proper scaling for different [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_dpi](~/includes/tla2sharptla-dpi-md.md)] settings and makes the application automatically [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_dpi](~/includes/tla2sharptla-dpi-md.md)]-aware.
However, this [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_dpi](~/includes/tla2sharptla-dpi-md.md)] independence can create irregular edge rendering due to anti-aliasing.
These artifacts, commonly seen as blurry, or "soft" edges, can occur when the location of an edge falls in the middle of a device pixel rather than between device pixels.

To address this issue, [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] provides a way for object edges in a visual tree to "snap" to device pixels through pixel snapping, eliminating the soft edges produced by anti-aliasing.
The vertical guideline.
